articles.headline: Rock-Bottom Interest Rates May Be Here to Stay
articles.snippet: Once the labor market begins to recover, the Federal Reserve’s experience in the pre-pandemic, record-long economic expansion is likely to influence when its raises rates.
articles.abstract: Once the labor market begins to recover, the Federal Reserve’s experience in the pre-pandemic, record-long economic expansion is likely to influence when its raises rates.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials were running a huge experiment with America’s job market before coronavirus lockdowns gripped the American economy, one that could inform how officials think about unemployment — and the path for interest rates — in the pandemic’s aftermath.

articles.headline: He Says Trumps Cost Him $2 Million, but Hotelier Now Cheers Federal Assist
articles.snippet: Plans to launch a brand of Trump hotels in Mississippi fizzled when the president’s family business walked away. Now a former partner has received  coronavirus relief loans as he completes the project.
articles.abstract: Plans to launch a brand of Trump hotels in Mississippi fizzled when the president’s family business walked away. Now a former partner has received  coronavirus relief loans as he completes the project.
articles.lead_paragraph: When President Trump was campaigning in 2016, his company announced a new line of bespoke hotels that would be built with partners across the country. But two years into his presidency, the Trump Organization shelved the brand and dropped the only partner, a Mississippi family business that one member says lost about $2 million in the collaboration.
articles.byline: By Steve Eder and Ben Protess

articles.headline: What Role Should Employers Play in Testing Workers?
articles.snippet: Amazon and other companies are planning to test workers for the coronavirus. But there is little federal guidance, and some fear it could lead to a false sense of security.
articles.abstract: Amazon and other companies are planning to test workers for the coronavirus. But there is little federal guidance, and some fear it could lead to a false sense of security.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the country reopens, employers are looking into how to safely bring back their workers. One recurring question: Should they be tested for the new coronavirus?
articles.byline: By Steve Eder, Ellen Gabler, Sarah Kliff and Heather Murphy

articles.headline: Firing a Salvo in Culture Wars, Trump Pushes for Churches to Reopen
articles.snippet: President Trump threatened to overrule states that refuse to open places of worship. The White House could not explain how he has that power, and legal experts said he did not have such authority.
articles.abstract: President Trump threatened to overrule states that refuse to open places of worship. The White House could not explain how he has that power, and legal experts said he did not have such authority.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump may not consider church essential to his personal life, but it may be to his political future. And so he waded into the culture wars on Friday by demanding that states allow places of worship to reopen “right away” and threatening to overrule any that defy him.

articles.headline: A Feud in Wolf-Kink Erotica Raises a Deep Legal Question
articles.snippet: What do copyright and authorship mean in the crowdsourced realm known as the Omegaverse?
articles.abstract: What do copyright and authorship mean in the crowdsourced realm known as the Omegaverse?
articles.lead_paragraph: Addison Cain was living in Kyoto, volunteering at a shrine and studying indigenous Japanese religion. She was supposed to be working on a scholarly book about her research, but started writing intensely erotic Batman fan fiction instead.

articles.headline: The Artisans Behind Italian Fashion Tremble at Their Future
articles.snippet: The industry has returned to work, but it’s far from business as usual for small suppliers to luxury brands and retailers.
articles.abstract: The industry has returned to work, but it’s far from business as usual for small suppliers to luxury brands and retailers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Until recently, some of the most intricately embroidered fabrics in the world, like those found in garments designed by Giorgio Armani, Valentino, Etro and Prada, have come out of a duplex apartment complex in Milan, the home of a small business called Pino Grasso Ricami.

articles.headline: Remembering the 100,000 Lives Lost to Coronavirus in America
articles.snippet: As the U.S. reached a grim milestone in the outbreak, The New York Times gathered names of the dead and memories of their lives from obituaries across the country.
articles.abstract: As the U.S. reached a grim milestone in the outbreak, The New York Times gathered names of the dead and memories of their lives from obituaries across the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the U.S. reached a grim milestone in the outbreak, The New York Times gathered names of the dead and memories of their lives from obituaries across the country.
articles.byline: By Dan Barry, Larry Buchanan, Clinton Cargill, Annie Daniel, Alain Delaquérière, Lazaro Gamio, Gabriel Gianordoli, Richard Harris, Barbara Harvey, John Haskins, Jon Huang, Simone Landon, Juliette Love, Grace Maalouf, Alex Matthews, Farah Mohamed, Steven Moity, Destinée-Charisse Royal, Matt Ruby and Eden Weingart

articles.headline: Pay Cuts Become a Tool for Some Companies to Avoid Layoffs
articles.snippet: “Shared sacrifice” in the white-collar ranks aims to avoid the cost of staffing up again. With no end to the crisis in sight, it is a leap of faith.
articles.abstract: “Shared sacrifice” in the white-collar ranks aims to avoid the cost of staffing up again. With no end to the crisis in sight, it is a leap of faith.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was late and Martin A. Kits van Heyningen feared he was letting the team down at the company he co-founded, KVH Industries. Rather than lay off workers in response to the coronavirus pandemic, he had decided to cut salaries, and when he emailed a video explaining his decision at 3 a.m. last month, he was prepared for a barrage of complaints.

articles.headline: Why China’s Move to Rein In Hong Kong Is Just the Start
articles.snippet: Xi Jinping’s China, emboldened by its handling of the coronavirus pandemic, no longer seems constrained by the threat of international rebuke.
articles.abstract: Xi Jinping’s China, emboldened by its handling of the coronavirus pandemic, no longer seems constrained by the threat of international rebuke.
articles.lead_paragraph: China’s move to strip away another layer of Hong Kong’s autonomy was not a rash impulse. It was a deliberate act, months in the making. It took into account the risks of international umbrage and reached the reasonable assumption that there would not be a significant geopolitical price to pay.

articles.headline: They Survived the Worst Battles of World War II. And Died of the Virus.
articles.snippet: Inside the Holyoke Soldiers’ Home was a man who had served as a jailer to Hitler’s top aide. A man who had rescued Japanese kamikaze pilots from the sea. A man who carried memories of a concentration camp.
articles.abstract: Inside the Holyoke Soldiers’ Home was a man who had served as a jailer to Hitler’s top aide. A man who had rescued Japanese kamikaze pilots from the sea. A man who carried memories of a concentration camp.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOLYOKE, Mass. — In 1945, James Leach Miller returned from the war and said nothing.

articles.headline: Trump Tweets and Golfs, but Makes No Mention of Virus’s Toll
articles.snippet: Coronavirus deaths in the United States approached a staggering 100,000, a number the president once predicted would never be reached.
articles.abstract: Coronavirus deaths in the United States approached a staggering 100,000, a number the president once predicted would never be reached.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As President Trump’s motorcade pulled into his golf club in Virginia on an overcast Sunday, a small group of protesters waited outside the entrance. One held up a sign.

articles.headline: The New Model Media Star Is Famous Only to You
articles.snippet: With short videos and paid newsletters, everyone from superstars to half-forgotten former athletes and even journalists can, as one tech figure put it, “monetize individuality.”
articles.abstract: With short videos and paid newsletters, everyone from superstars to half-forgotten former athletes and even journalists can, as one tech figure put it, “monetize individuality.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Back in March, I was trying to persuade my dad to stop taking the subway to work in Manhattan and join me upstate. So I paid $75 to Leonard Marshall, a retired New York Giants defensive lineman we both loved in the 1980s, to send the message.

articles.headline: The Coronavirus Is Deadliest Where Democrats Live
articles.snippet: Beyond perception and ideology, there are starkly different realities for red and blue America right now.
articles.abstract: Beyond perception and ideology, there are starkly different realities for red and blue America right now.
articles.byline: By Jennifer Medina and Robert Gebeloff

articles.headline: As Passengers Disappeared, Airlines Filled Planes With Cargo
articles.snippet: To make up for lost revenue during the pandemic, Lufthansa, Virgin Atlantic and other airlines are hauling more cargo on aircraft, including where passengers used to sit.
articles.abstract: To make up for lost revenue during the pandemic, Lufthansa, Virgin Atlantic and other airlines are hauling more cargo on aircraft, including where passengers used to sit.
articles.lead_paragraph: Most passenger planes today fly virtually empty, but when Virgin Atlantic flight VS251 landed at Heathrow Airport near London on a cloudy afternoon late last month, most of its 258 seats were occupied.
articles.byline: By Niraj Chokshi, Felix Schmitt and Tom Jamieson

articles.headline: African-Americans Are Highly Visible in the Military, but Almost Invisible at the Top
articles.snippet: Seventy-five years after integration, the military’s upper echelons remain the domain of white men.
articles.abstract: Seventy-five years after integration, the military’s upper echelons remain the domain of white men.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A photograph of President Trump and his top four-star generals and admirals, tweeted in October by Defense Secretary Mark T. Esper, was meant as a thank-you to the commander in chief. But it angered a lot of others, and not just those who erupted on Twitter.

articles.headline: Wealthiest Hospitals Got Billions in Bailout for Struggling Health Providers
articles.snippet: Twenty large chains received more than $5 billion in federal grants even while sitting on more than $100 billion in cash.
articles.abstract: Twenty large chains received more than $5 billion in federal grants even while sitting on more than $100 billion in cash.
articles.lead_paragraph: A multibillion-dollar institution in the Seattle area invests in hedge funds, runs a pair of venture capital funds and works with elite private equity firms like the Carlyle Group.
articles.byline: By Jesse Drucker, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Sarah Kliff

articles.headline: On a Scottish Isle, Nursing Home Deaths Expose a Covid-19 Scandal
articles.snippet: At the Home Farm nursing home on the Isle of Skye, more than a quarter of its residents died and nearly all were infected with coronavirus. Families are furious.
articles.abstract: At the Home Farm nursing home on the Isle of Skye, more than a quarter of its residents died and nearly all were infected with coronavirus. Families are furious.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the Isle of Skye off the western coast of Scotland, residents thought they had sealed themselves off from the coronavirus. They shuttered hotels. Officials warned of police checks. Traffic emptied on the only bridge from the mainland.
